instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1708: What is A1708? A1708 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2017, 2016 with EMC 3164, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00840, 820-00875..
definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT? PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the LED light in the screen of the device that allows you to see what is on the screen. When this is low or missing, the screen will be dim..
definitions.BKLT_SCL: What is BKLT_SCL? BKLT_SCL is an I2C signal clock line between the LED driver that creates the LCD backlight power rail that powers the backlight in the screen and the screen. The screen needs to speak to the LED driver on this line before backlight voltage will be created..
definitions.BKLT_SDA: What is BKLT_SDA? BKLT_SDA is a data line between the LCD screen and the LED driver. This data line cannot short to ground. If it does, the screen cannot talk to the LED driver, and the LED driver will not allow the circuit to produce a backlight..
definitions.BKLT_SD: What is BKLT_SD? BKLT_SD is a pin of the LED driver that goes to the voltage divider that feeds the gate of the transistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H and the backlight circuit. The LED driver will short this pin to ground when backlight circuit is ready to turn on. Prerequisites are 1) it is told to turn on via enable signal, the screen has communicated with the LED driver 2) current sensing circuit is working 3) does not detect an over-current situation such as the backlight power rail being shorted to ground.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message:
Hi,

I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A that has no backlight. Already trued with a known good lcd, but no success.

I get 13V on F8400 but I get 0V on <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL>.

On <DIODE>D8410</DIODE> I get 0V and on diode reading I get on 0,394V and 0.940V on the pads.

Can you help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message:
Do you get image for sure?
<SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL> goes high?
Test external video, if no internal image at all.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message:
Hi,
I get image, on internal and on external also. Its backlight.
On <CHIP>U8400</CHIP> I get 3.3v on EN

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message:
Check <RESISTOR>R8450</RESISTOR>-53 and their traces.
Post voltage and diode mode at SCL/SDA lines.
<CHIP>U8400</CHIP> receives backlight adjust from PCH, via T-CON (inside LCD assembly), through I2C protocol.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R8450</RESISTOR>-53  seams to be ok 1.4K ohms and traces seams to be ok

Diode:
<SIGNAL>BKLT_SCL</SIGNAL> = 0,549V
<SIGNAL>BKLT_SDA</SIGNAL> = 0.549V

Voltage:
<SIGNAL>BKLT_SCL</SIGNAL> = 4.5V
<SIGNAL>BKLT_SDA</SIGNAL> = 4.5V

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message:
All 1.4K???
I could swear two of them are 0 ohm...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message:
Sorry, I only measured <RESISTOR>R8450</RESISTOR> and 8453 (those are 1.4k). 
<RESISTOR>R8451</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R8452</RESISTOR> are 0 ohms

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message:
Keep in mind, x1-3 means x1, x2 and x3; x1/2 means x1 and x2.
Just in case, x/y1/2 means x1, x2, y1 and y2; example R/<CAPACITOR>C7030</CAPACITOR>/40 (look at 00840 board).
We use many times such kind of short names in the forum.

Try changing <CHIP>U8400</CHIP>.
Any history available?
<SIGNAL>BKLT_SD</SIGNAL> stays low?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message:
OK, tks for the explanation.

I've replaced <CHIP>U8400</CHIP> but same result, and <SIGNAL>BLKT_SDA</SIGNAL>/SCL still 4.5V.

The client says that it was working and the screen turn black. It has no signs off liquid damage or corrosion.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message:
Check/replace <CHIP>U8400</CHIP> surrounding components.
Be sure to have good solders and traces.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message:
Hi.

<RESISTOR>R8432</RESISTOR> should be 150k ohm (and it is), but when I solder it back, I get 16k resistance to ground on it. Is this value normal or do I have a problem with the backlight feedback?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message:
Is normal to get lower reading for high value resistor measured onboard; other components simulate parallel resistor.

"I only measured <RESISTOR>R8450</RESISTOR> and 8453 (those are 1.4k)"
Look at schematic and check again the four resistors...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message:
Hi,
I mesured all resistors around <CHIP>U8400</CHIP> and all of them are with the right values and their traces seams to be ok.
<RESISTOR>R8451</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R8452</RESISTOR> are 0 ohms. 
Can it be <TRANSISTOR>Q8401</TRANSISTOR>?. On <CHIP>U8400</CHIP> i get 0v on  <SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_SW</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message:
"<RESISTOR>R8451</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R8452</RESISTOR> are 0 ohms"
Check schematic again...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message:
Sorry, writing error:
<RESISTOR>R8450</RESISTOR> = 0 0hm
<RESISTOR>R8451</RESISTOR> = 0 0hm
<RESISTOR>R8452</RESISTOR> = 13.7 K ohm
<RESISTOR>R8453</RESISTOR> = 13.7 K ohm

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no backlight
threads.message: If <CHIP>U8400</CHIP> is good, there could be I2C communication problem; like LCD assembly, video cable/connector, or bad traces.
